facts.text: Goa was a Portuguese colony for about 450 years until occupied by Indian Armed Forces on December 19, 1961 following short military action.
Goa came under Indian Administration from December 20, 1961 and governed under Goa, Daman and Diu Administration Ordinance 1962, later Act 1 of 1962.
Constitution (Twelfth Amendment) Act, 1962 included Goa in Union Territories, deemed effective from December 20, 1961, inserting reference in Art. 240.
Citizenship Act 1955, Foreigners Act 1946, Registration of Foreigners Act 1939 extended to Goa.

Goa, Daman and Diu (Citizenship) Order 1962 promulgated under S.7 Citizenship Act: persons born in Goa before Dec 20, 1961 deemed Indian citizens unless declared retention of prior nationality within one month.
Appellant Rev. Father Monteiro, resident of Goa, declared retention of Portuguese nationality on April 27, 1962 pursuant to Citizenship Order.
Appellant registered as foreigner, obtained temporary residential permit allowing stay till November 13, 1964.
Appellant applied for residential permit on August 14, 1964 but failed to apply for renewal after expiry.
Lt. Governor of Goa (empowered under Art. 239 notification to discharge Central Government functions) ordered appellant to leave India on June 19, 1965.
Appellant disobeyed order and prosecuted under S.14 read with S.3(2)(c) of Foreigners Act.
Appellant convicted and sentenced to 30 days simple imprisonment and fine of Rs.50/- or 5 days further simple imprisonment.
Appeal to Court of Session dismissed; revision to Judicial Commissioner, Goa dismissed on August 7, 1967.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant protected by Geneva Conventions Act, 1960 against deportation order, as occupation of Goa continues notwithstanding annexation.
Whether order of Lt. Governor tantamount to prohibited deportation under Art.49 of Fourth Geneva Convention.
Whether application of Foreigners Act to appellant competent post-annexation.
Whether Geneva Conventions Act creates enforceable rights in municipal courts against government.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of Lt. Governor is deportation prohibited by Art.49 Geneva Conventions; protection continues as occupation not ended by unilateral annexation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Geneva Conventions Act 1960, Fourth Schedule Arts.1,2,4,6,8,47,49; International Law (Oppenheim, Jennings, Dholakia)

petitioner_arguments.text: Geneva Conventions create individual rights not waivable; must be read with International Law; conquest does not confer title post-UN Charter.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.47,49 Fourth Convention; Heydon's case rule; Art.158,159,77 Conventions

petitioner_arguments.text: Annexation does not deprive protected persons of benefits; occupation ends only by cession or withdrawal.

respondent_arguments.text: Occupation means belligerent occupation by armed forces, ends by conquest and subjugation; true annexation occurred.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: International Law (Oppenheim, Greenspan, Brierly); Hague Regulations Art.42

respondent_arguments.text: State has right to regulate entry/residence of aliens; Foreigners Act applies.

court_reasoning.text: Reception and residence of aliens matter of state discretion; Foreigners Act applicable to appellant as Portuguese national.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Every State has competence to exclude aliens by territorial supremacy.

court_reasoning.text: Geneva Conventions Act implements international obligations but creates no enforceable individual rights in municipal courts; only penalties for breaches.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No cause of action for protected persons against government.

court_reasoning.text: Occupation defined per Hague Reg. Art.42 as territory under authority of hostile army (belligerent occupation); supplements Geneva Conventions per Art.154.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Post-conquest subjugation and annexation ends occupation.

court_reasoning.text: True annexation (not premature) occurred on Dec 20, 1961: no resistance, full administration taken over, no hostile army.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Annexation by conquest/subjugation creates de jure title; Geneva protections cease.

court_reasoning.text: Art.6 Fourth Convention: application ceases one year after close of military operations in occupied territory, but protections limited post-hostilities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.47/49 apply to belligerent occupation, not post-subjugation.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant retained Portuguese nationality, must comply with permit requirements; rightly prosecuted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: National status post-subjugation determined by subjugating state.

holdings.text: Belligerent occupation ended by true annexation on Dec 20, 1961; Geneva Conventions protections ceased; Foreigners Act applies.
Geneva Conventions Act creates no private right of action in municipal courts.
Order not prohibited deportation under Art.49 as no ongoing occupation.

precedents_cited.relevance: Alien cannot enforce right of entry in municipal courts; state discretion over aliens.

precedents_cited.case_name: United States v. Alstoetter et al.
precedents_cited.citation: 1947 U.S. Military Tribunal, Nuremberg L.R. 3 T.W.C. vi, 34
precedents_cited.relevance: Laws of belligerent occupation apply only during warfare; cease after total defeat.
Title by history not necessary here due to immediate subjugation.

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to prosecute appellant for disobeying expulsion order as foreigner.

statutes_cited.name: Citizenship Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for Goa Citizenship Order deeming residents citizens unless declared otherwise.

statutes_cited.name: Geneva Conventions Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Implements 1949 Conventions; no private enforcement rights; punishes breaches.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Lt. Governor empowered as Central Govt.; basis for Twelfth Amendment including Goa; enables treaties implementation.

statutes_cited.name: Goa, Daman and Diu (Administration) Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Replaced Ordinance; extended Indian laws to Goa.

statutes_cited.name: Goa, Daman and Diu (Citizenship) Order, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Deemed citizenship unless declaration to retain prior nationality.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under Foreigners Act upheld as Geneva Conventions do not apply post-annexation and subjugation of Goa; appellant as Portuguese national subject to expulsion for overstaying permit.

key_quotes.text: A territory is considered as occupied when it finds itself in fact placed under the authority of a hostile army.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts Hague Reg. Art.42 definition to interpret Geneva Conventions.

key_quotes.text: Protected persons who are in occupied territory shall not be deprived... of the benefits of the present Convention... by any annexation by the latter of the whole or part of the occupied territory.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Art.47 but holds applies only to belligerent, not post-subjugation, occupation.

key_quotes.text: The subjugating state can... allow them to emigrate, and to renounce their newly acquired citizenship, and its Municipal Law can put them in any position it likes.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites Oppenheim on post-subjugation nationality control.
